stem: A client has been receiving long-term TPN with 20% lipid emulsion daily. Based on the documentation in the Lipid & Coagulation Surveillance Log, which condition is the client most likely developing?

tabs.title: Serum Lab Trends
tabs.content:
TestBaselineCurrent (Week 3)
Serum Triglycerides140 mg/dL1,150 mg/dL (Critical)
Platelets220,00054,000 (Low)
ALT / AST24 / 28210 / 195 (High)
Serum Ammonia22 mcg/dL82 mcg/dL (High)

tabs.title: Nursing Assessment
tabs.content: Current: Client is febrile (Temp 102.2°F). Abdomen is distended; palpable splenomegaly (enlarged spleen) and hepatomegaly noted. Client reports 'bone pain' and malaise.

tabs.title: Nutritional Log
tabs.content:
Formulation: 2-in-1 TPN with separate fat emulsion (Intralipid 20%).
Rate: Administered at 30 mL/hr continuously for 21 days.

rationale.correct: This is **Lipid Overload Syndrome (a1)**. When IV lipids are given too rapidly or over too long a period, the triglycerides can spike (> 1,000 mg/dL) and overwhelm the body's reticuloendothelial system (the 'cleanup' system involving the liver and spleen). This leads to the 'overload triad': **Fever**, **Splenomegaly/Hepatomegaly**, and **Thrombocytopenia** (low platelets). This is a life-threatening complication that requires immediate cessation of the lipid infusion.
clinicalPearls: Triglycerides > 400 = Risk of pancreatitis. Triglycerides > 1,000 = Risk of Overload Syndrome.
The 'fats' literally clog the spleen and liver, preventing them from filtering blood normally.
Management: Stop the fats, monitor for clotting issues (DIC), and restart at a much slower rate once cleared.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing 'Simple Hypertriglyceridemia' (a2) because the number is high.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If there is **Fever** and **Organ Enlargement** (Splenomegaly), it is no longer just a 'high lab'—it is a 'Syndrome' affecting the whole body. Always look for the 'Systemic' cues.
